div.l: LONDON, Printed by I. Raworth, for R. Whitaker. 1640.

div.head: The names of the persons.
div.l: Hartwell, a young Gentleman, Lover of Mistresse Frances.
Three Servants, disguised sometimes as Lords, one of them once disguised as a Pursevant.

div.stage: Enter Hartwell, Close, and three other Servants.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay let’s not part so heavily.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: For mine owne part
It does not trouble me so much, that you
Have broke up house; for hospitalitie

Went out of fashion with crop-doublets
†crop-doublet. A short doublet. Obsolete.(OED n. C3).
doublet. A close-fitting body-garment, with or without sleeves, worn by men from the 14th to the 18th centuries. (Rarely applied to a similar garment worn by women.) Obsolete exc. Historical. (OED n. 1a).

And cod-peeces cod-peeces A (padded) pouch attached to the front of a man's close-fitting hose or breeches to cover the genitals, commonly worn in the 15th and 16th cent. (OED “codpiece”, n. 1a).: but I that have worne out
So many liveries under the worshipfull
Old Gentleman your father.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: My father had an office, which brought in
A faire revenew; I inherit but
His little land, whose annuall profits wo'not
Encourage me to live at the same height:
Yee may meet better fortunes, there's enough
Preferment in the world; my love and best
Assistance promise to your selves.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I do not
Stand upon wages, Sir, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: How woot thou live?

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: As other mortals do; yet I'll not play
The thiefe, that is a course by which a man
May soone ascend the ladder of preferment:
But I ne're lov'd these climbing trees. I cannot
Cheat, though I have heard there is an art,
A devillish deale of knowledge in the dice;
And if men wonot part with money, some
Will fetch it out o'th' bones: but the best casting
Is in a Taverne, when the wine and reckoning
Come up together; some doe spin a living by't:
And there are many secret wayes for Serving-men
To live, it is not wages does maintaine
All of our Tribe, Sir; and especially
Those that have Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: But I am a BachelourIn the 17th and 18th centuries, it was common in English-language texts to capitalise the first letter of common “important” nouns, probably as a result of the influence of continental, particularly German, books. However, this was not done systematically; one reason may be that each printer had their own personal preferences. .

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I pray let me be one of your buttons still then,
I am not halfe worne out; you know what mould
I'm made off, I did ever honest service;
And though my fellow Vermin can forsake
Your falling house, I doe not feare the rafters;
By this hand, Sir, I'll wait upon you, though
Like great mens servants, I do live on nothing
But looks, and the aire of commendations.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, attend me,
The rest I here discharge, there's somewhat more,
Not worth the name of bountie, I wish all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: And there be
No remedy, heaven blesse you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with these
My fellowes, sorrow has made but a dry proverb,
I must toth' Taverne, and condole a quart.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Meet me at Mistresse Bellamy’s then.

div.fw: The Constant Maid, Act I Scene I

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: How now Masters.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: You speake not
To me, Sir, I am a servant still indeed;
With them the case is alter'd, they are masters,
For they want services.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: Oh, Master Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: It is not now as when Andrea liv'dAs the 1833 editor points out, some of the lines said by the servants in this passage are taken from Hieronimo’s monologue in scene V of The Spanish Tragedy, a very popular and influential play in the English Renaissance theatre written by Thomas Kyd between 1582 and 1592. ,

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: This place was made for pleasure, not for death.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: There was a time when mortals whetted knives.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: In time of yore, when men kill'd brutish beasts.

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: Oh cruell Butcher, whosoe're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Do not you know what all this signifies?

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: My master has given over house-keeping.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: He has committed Burglarie, broke up the cellar,
And throwne the kitchin out at the hall window.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: His house, Sir, has a superscription,
And is directed to his loving friend
Will pay the rent, you'l hardly know me now,
I have no fellow.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: You are verie merrie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: He has some cause, we are discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: For certaine, my master only
Belongs to me, if you would speake with him,
He's gone to Mistresse Bellamy’s, Sir;
In the meane time, please you to understand,
I Close follow my master, and shall feed still,
Although my fellowes here are become blanks,
And do want filling.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Lads, I have knowne you long:
Although you be at losse, in confidence
Of all your future honesties, I'll employ yee
In a device, which if it hit, may
Reward your paines.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Your Master only, Sir, belongs to you,
Follow him still, and if there be occasion,
I shall enquire for you; you will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Servants Omnes
sp.l: Doubt not, Mr. Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I have a project,
Follow me for instructions; farewell Close,
Commend me to your master.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: Buoy Close, buoy honest Close, we are blanks, blanks.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Roule up your selves in paper-liveries, and
Be drawne at the next Lotterie; I wo'not
Forsake my certaintie for all your projects,
If it should faile I shall find some of you

Sneaking in Paul'sClose is most probably referring to the Old St Paul’s Cathedral, which was destroyed shortly afterwards in the Great Fire of London in 1666 and rebuilt as we know it today. Despite its decay at the time, the cathedral was in the 17th century one of the focal points of London’s cultural, literary and political life, as well as a popular pilgrimage site. behind a pillar, with
A zealous prayer, some Gentleman would read

The bed-roll†bed-roll. A list of persons to be specially prayed for. Obsolete or archaic.(OED “bead-roll”, n. 1). of your commendationcommendation.An office originally ending with the prayer Tibi, Domine, commendamus, in which the souls of the dead were commended to God; said both before their burial, and in anniversary or commemorative services. Liturgical (gen. In plural; also Commendation of Souls). (OED n. II. 6a). Commendatory prayer (OED n. II. 6b).,
And pitie a verie serviceable fellow,
That would faine wait on him, but wants a cloake:
Go, prosper with your project.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy’s House.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Widdow, be rul'd by me, I know the world,
And I have studied it these fiftie yeares:
There's no man to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Without good.
Securitie, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No young man, widdow,
That talks, and sayes he loves you, writes you verses,
And sweares he shall goe hang himselfe, unlesse
You pitie him; take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: So, take you an old man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Season'd with care and thrift, not led away
By vicious conversation, nor corrupted
With pride and surfeit, one that knowes the use
Of money; Do yee mark the use?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, Sir:
Use upon use, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And dares not spend it prodigally, knowing
The principall end it was ordain'd to, was
To releeve our necessitie, and lay up
What is above.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: To help the poore.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You may,
If you be so dispos'd, but 'tis as commendable
To give it in your will, to build an Hospitall,
And so our charitie comes altogether:
I would not have your state be eaten up
By Catterpillers, but preserv'd and made
Greater, by marrying some discreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And such an one you show your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You happily
Interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I would not tell you, Sir,
Till our next meeting, how much you have won,
By your good counsell, on me.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She inclines.
'Tis your good nature, I am plaine, and have
No tricks, I'll tell you all my fault, I am
Addicted verie much to gather wealth;
I have no children to devoure my state,
Nor kinred, only a Neece left to my trust,
One that is never like to marrie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She never thriv'd since she came to mee.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I easily beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Melancholly
Will kill her, and yet I pursue all wayes
That promise her delight: I spare no cost
Of Physick, what her Doctor sayes, is done.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis lovingly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Gentleman that beares my daughter much
Affection.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Sure I have seene him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, he's a beggar, or must be verie shortly.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have you his lands in morgage?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Not yet, not yet; but he'll want money, widdow.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: He has had good breeding.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unlucky,
They never keep their state that have too much on't,
Counsell your daughter, Mistresse Bellamy,
To throw him off betime†betime.In good time, early, seasonably. Obsolete. (OED adv. 1)..

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You direct well.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: When we are married, I'll provide a match for her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You have care on's.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: It will become me.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is he Suitor to your mother, Lady?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: He would be such a thing: Were not I blest
In such a jolly father in law?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: He looks like some cast money-bag, that had given up
The stuffing, and for want of use growne mouldy:
He dares not keep much fire in's kitchin, lest
Warming his hands, which rather looke like gloves,
So tann'd and thin, he let em scorch, and gather
Into a heap. I do not think he ever
Put off his clothes, he would run-mad to see
His owne anatomy, that such a wretch
Should have so vast a wealth.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I wod not be his
Niece for all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I presume
Your mother is more noble, than to encourage him
In his pretence, and her estate would mix
But ill with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widdowes and from or plans, nor will all
His plentie keep his soule one day from famine:
'Tis time ill spent to mention him, let's talk
Of something else.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Of love agen,
Whose flame we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they shut up doores
First, that keep open house and entertainments:
This Lord is feasted, and that young Ladies
Sweet tooth must have a banquet; t'other old
Madam with ne're a tooth must have some marchpanemarchpane.Historical for “marzipan”.
Corall to rub her gums withall; these are
Ridiculous expences.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Far from thrift.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: This roome has too rich furniture, and worse
Hangings would serve the turne; if I may be
Worthy to counsell, costly pictures are
Superfluous, though of this, or t'other masters
Doing: Hang Michael AngeloMichelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (1475-1564), Italian Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect and poet. and his oyles.
If they be given, y'are the more excus'd
To let 'em shew; but have a care you let not
Appeare, either in Arras, or in picture,

The storie of the ProdigallHornet advises Bellamy not to display art depicting the Parable of the Prodigal Son, one of the parables of Jesus Christ in the Bible, appearing in Luke 15:11-32. The parable is framed as a response to a criticism of Jesus by the Pharisees and scribes for receiving sinners and eating with them, and emphasises God’s mercy towards the repentant. Hornet seems to warn that, if Bellamy shows this parable to her young male guests, they may restrict how much they spend on their dowries., 'twill fright
Young Gentlemen that come to visit you
From spending o'their portions, whose riot
May enrich you with their forfeited estates;
I have a thousand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But do not
Think all this while of heaven.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis in my chest,
And multiplyed in everie bag.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Or Hell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A fable to fright fooles, or children; but
I cannot stay, my Scrivener doth expect me,
I'll visit you another time, sweet widdow,
And give you more instructions.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Spare your travell
I sha'not practise these in haste, and must
Declare these precepts make not for your welcome:
My patience was a vertue all this while,
If you but think you have a soule; repent;
Your rules I am not covetous to follow,
Good master Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Live and be undone then:
You'l tell me another tale hereafter widdow.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Letters from Master Startup, the countrey Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A Sutor of my Nurses commendations.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Now heaven deliver me, what have I seen?
This monster once was shewne i'th' faire, or such
Another furr'd Baboone for all the world,
Do'st know him? Why do I ask such a question?
He's such a thing the Devill would not owne's
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Master Hornet, the great Usurer.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Hornet? Nay then, my wonder's over, and the
Devill be but such another, they
May be sworne brothers; yes, and divide hell
Betwixt em.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who is that you talk on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: The beast, that Heaven be thank'd, has left you,
Hornet; but I ha newes for you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I'll heare it in the garden.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Do you love
That Master Hartwell? do not blush, but answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I hope you move†move.Transitive. To propose or suggest (something to be done); to prefer (a request); to lodge (a complaint); to bring forward, propound (a question, etc.), mention (a matter). Also with to (a person). Obsolete. (OED v. 30a). not this, as if you doubted;
I took him first, upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But things alter:
What then I thought, I deliver'd yee;
Nor since hath he deserv'd a lesse esteeme
In his owne person, but the circumstance
Is not the same, his fortune I have examin'd,
Which rises not to such a value, I
Did apprehend; and it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my estate, to look for one whose purse
May carrie a proportion.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of shining dust, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nor
To penurie; his birth, and education
Are not unworthy, he's a handsome man too;
But be not govern'd by your eye too much:
Children and age pursue, and many stormes
Hover about our fraile conditions:
All these must be provided for, they are not
Kisses will arme you against winter, therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your best thoughts,

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Oh my unhappinesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Countrey Gentleman of spreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not spun the finest, but his wealth,
Able to guild deformitie, and make
Even want of wit a vertue, when your life
Renders it selfe more sweet by your command;
His name is Master Startup, whom I expect
Our guest to morrow, that's his letter, read it.
This may seeme strange at the first coming toward you;
But when discretion comes to examine what
A fruitfull consequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother,
Although I could dispence with my owne thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for my honour, or my fame? when such
A noble Gentleman shall boast he had,
With your consent, my love? or pray admit
That which we gaine by riches of the second,
Seeme to authorize, and may justifie
The act with some; how can it cure the wound,
Which the poore heart, which loves, shall find too soone,
When 'tis neglected, and so cruelly,
Where it did hope for cherishing? Oh think
How you did love my father first, and be
More gentle to your daughter, your estate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new stock; it doth grow already
Faire from his owne root, and doth want no peecing:
Nor are the meanes of Hartwell so contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: No more: y'have consider'd well, you'l shape
Another answer; i'th' meane time dispose
Your countenance to entertaine this new
And able Lover: leave the satisfaction
Of Hartwell to my care:
He's here, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themselves yet;
But he has a project to employ 'em all.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I wish it well; but do you work your selfe
Into the opinion of her Nurse, she is
The Major Domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her Sir like wax,
To print what forme you please upon her, 'tis
A Loving Crone already to me, I
Will speake her faire, and in my drink may marrie her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: About your businesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: There is a matter, Sir, which I must open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You prepare my attention.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
At least I think so.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident, in her I sum
All my desires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Be not so fixt.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: How Lady?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: When you have heard me out, you'l find
Your consent easie to call back a promise
Made to your disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I acknowledge;
This makes me wonder, pray interpret Lady,
And speake the dialect I understand:
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But must never glorie
In the reward which you expect should be,
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guiltie of so much
Offence to you, that I should be so soone
Lost to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have no thought so poore
You can deserve lesse, my opinion
Is richer laden with your merit.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Now I feare agen, this violent turne of praise
Makes me suspect my state; if I be falne,
Teach me to know my trespasse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I ne're look'd
With such cleere eyes into your worth, and 'twere
A sin to generall goodnesse, to delay
The free resigne of that your worth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my mistake
Of something went before, love made me feare;
You said I never should enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which your selfe so late enclined to.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And must agen repeat, you cannot call
Her Bride.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Can you forbid this happinesse,
And love me?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, so deerly, Hartwell, I
Present my selfe to thy affection.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You fright my understanding.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Does the name
Of widdow sound displeasing, I have learn'd
Already to obey; my yeares are not
So many, with the thought, to freeze your bloud,
I weare no print of time deep in my brow:
Have my haires the innocence of age,
To speake me twice a child? Gentlemen active,
And of great birth, have courted my affection
And if they flatter not, commend my person.
Adde unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter,
Depending on my love, whose portion must
Flow from my bountie, or be nothing; make
A sober apprehension of this tender,
And think I was not able to suppresse
My silent flame, increast still by your vertues:
This minute give all hopes up for my daughter,
I can admit no Rivall; 'tis within
Your election to be happie, Sir:
My love accepted comes with faire attendance,
Deny'd, you hasten your owne exile, think on't,
I will expect your answer.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I am destroy'd:
Was it her mother that spake all this while?
As pilgrims, by mistake of some small path,
Having told many wearie steps, at night,
When their hopes flatter em, they are not far
From some kind entertainment, find themselves
Lost in a wildernesse; so am I miserable:
Thus love delights to wound, and see us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Fye, fie, I am asham'd of you, a Gentleman
Of your high promising, and be put off
So slightly?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why Nurse, what would you ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Do? I would have you do something; a man
Of your ability, and cannot turne
And winde a woman?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: You wo'd not ha' wish'd me
To ha' put her to't behinde the hangings?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You should ha' been round with her.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I was round with her, I call'd her asse and coxcombe,
And twenty more names, unlesse I should
Ha' call'd her whore, I could not be more round with her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I do not mean that way.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: And she call'd me,
I thank her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why no worse than her sins, heaven forgive her,
She has the more to answer; nay she did
Not stick to bid me die too, in that desparate
Estate.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come, you shall take another course.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What ayles my Masters sweet-heart, she frighted?
I met and askt her for my Master, and
She turn'd tayle lik a hound had lost the scent;
There's something in the winde, my three pil'd worship
Are you there with my Lady o'th' Larder,
Now in that posture? do not they two look like
A fine Brick house and a thatched Barne in the Countrey,
Laying their heads together? they ha' spied me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come hither Close, nay he's faithfull, and one that
Has a desire to serve you; you may trust him.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Your worship may trust me a bed with— I
Have had a itch this great while, sir, a kinde
Of longing to be one of your appurtenances:
I have some faults, and I'll confesse 'em; I have
A humour now and then, when I am ask'd
A question, to tell true, though I be chid for't;
And I do not love blowes; you may sooner beat
My braines out, than a word of flattery:
I cannot batten upon commendation,
Without my wages, nor be valiant
Upon small Beere; I am not overmuch
Given to be drunke, but I've a tricke o'th Dutchman,
To do your businesse as well drunke as sober:
I have not impudence enough to pimpe
For you, but I have a gift I can say nothing:
I was borne upon Shrovetuesday, and shall be
Now and then given to rebellion:
My flesh will once a year rise at a Chamber-maid;
If none such take me downe, I shall in malice
And deep revenge, fling out upon May-day,
Among the Prentices, without fear or wit.
And she may be compell'd to marry him in
Her owne defence; there have been such devises.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Does he consent?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: She is betraid to't, sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Then thou wo't be so base?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And I had meant it,
I never had told you this: can you make use
Of this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Thou art my honest servant.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I promis'd to be his.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I have it; Canst
By any meanes procure me but his clothes?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: With ease, he'll go to bed betimes, to avoid
Suspicion; that's a part of our designe.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I could not wish a happy opportunity,
To try how she affects this gaudy foole,
And clear my faith to her, which her mothers watch
Will not permit; she has, I feare, perceiv'd
My new familiarity with her mother,
Which I am compell'd too, and must cleer this way:
Faile me not, Close, and propound thy owne
Reward.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Tell me your purpose, and let my wit
Dispose of him.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Prosper me love in this.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And you fall to prayers
With good love, look about us, I shall suspect
You wo'not thrive; you should go to a wench,
As Gentlemen to Oysters, without ceremony
Or saying grace; devotion will spoile all.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House. A banquet set out.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Right as an Arrow Couze.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Witty enginere;
But was she taken with the plot?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I was compell'd to frame the outside of a reason,
Lest our owne mirth should play the Traytor with us,
Her spleene was so dilated, he beleeved
I have made her mad, which change makes for us.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: And he that we employed, the Pursevant,
Shewed such a fierie Raskall, the poore Usurer
Trembled, as Bawds beneath the lash.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: He comes then?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: With as much joy, as to receive a hanging:
He would be whipt, and say his prayers i'th' Church
In a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: That were no pennance to him.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Nay, he would pay as much as he should fine
For Alderman, though halfe his soule went with it,
For his quietnesse; he doth apprehend
Nothing but earth-quakes.

div.stage: Enter three servants, disguised as Lords.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: How am I rampant
With the imagination? bid the musick
Be ready, they know all their flourishes;
But shift you quickly for your other part,
My honourable Lords;
How they doe look like States-man, where's your tooth-pick?
Excellent; beare your staffe handsomely, contract
The brow, and look more superciliously.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: I warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: We came now
From practise.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Can ye do't with confidence?

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: These verie clothes have made me proud already,
It was some Lords cast sute, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And mine, it smels of honour.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so, how now man?

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He looks pale: My Lord, how d'ee?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well, well, I hope 'tis but conceit.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Will the pox lie in clothes? I can not tell,
I finde some alteration in my body,
Since I shifted.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: 'Tis a meere conceit,
They were an honest mans, upon my knowledge,
A Captaine of the traine Band in the Countrey,
They were brought against the generall Master last;
He wore 'em that day, and to Church the Sunday
Following, and most carefully sent 'em up,
To taste our London Lavender.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Sir, you have satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Be sprightly; where's this Prince?
See and attend him in fit state.

div.stage: Re-enter Cousen disguised as the King, and three servants as Lords, Sir Clement.
Cousen sits himself at the head of the board.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Now by that sprig, a pretty Majesty;
But wo't thou not be out of thy Kings part?
And when the Wine is wanting at the Banquet,
Call upon drawers, quarrell with your Nobles,
Or when we shall present our man of morgages,
Take him aside, and borrow halfe a crowne,
To give your whore benevolence, which trusted,
For you last tilting, or be drunke too soone,
And leave our project in the dirt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Lords,
This fellowes insolence must be corrected;
Dispose him in what prison you think fit.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He's mad, I thinke.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To Bedlam with him then,
Is this a place for fools or madmen, who
Admitted him? take him, see you
He be well whipt, and let him thanke our mercy,
Bandog.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I quake already, excellent Warbeck,
Coole, coole thy lungs, and whisper with some Lord,
Thou wo't be a key too high else, good Sir Clement,
Master of the house, at whose cost we are entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: My part is rotten
In my head, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: He waits in the first chamber.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Let the Lutes
Begin, and their best voice, and then admit him.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Here's revelling, my purse must be squeez'd for't:
That's the King, the rest are bare; how supple they are
I'th hams, that Courtier has Oyl'd his joynts,
He looks this way, they point at me; a rot
O'that knave’s finger.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: What fellow's this? who waits?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: It was his graces pleasure, he was sent for,
My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Mr. Hornet?
Let me have the honour to present him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is this the man whom all so much commend
For his ability.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I smell no good from that word, ability.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Discreet and read i'th' Common-wealth, a man
Fit for employment in the State.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His countenance is promising.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: If the King of Spaine
Had but his head, that politick head,
I know who might go fish for the Low-Countreyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His garments are but course.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: His minde is rich.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: They praise me, I am a thousand pound the worse for’t.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Wilt please your Majesty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Kneel downe; Thy name?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Giles Hornet, your poore creature.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Rise up, Sir Giles Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But am I Knighted?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: We congratulate your honour.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What must I pay for it?
I'll sell it any friend of yours againe,
For halfe the money.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some have care to give
His body more becomming ornaments;
He shall be like himselfe, and then we will confer
More honors on him.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do you make haste, his Grace
Will have you new thatch'd; you must have clothes
Fitting your State and honorable title.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: These will be good enough for me, 'las I am not able.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Nay, you must have 'em from his Wardrobe, sir,
They'll cost you nothing; You'll not looke in those,
Like a poore Knight of Windsor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: When he is ready, give us knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Yes, sir.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Hornet and Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You were best prepare,
Your cloathes will be here presently, the King
Will send for you before you be ready; Cast
Your old skin off: Do you not to save sheets
And trouble, wrap your selves a nights i'th blankets?
Or are they ashamed to show the Linings?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hum? if this be but preparative to a whipping,
What case am I in?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well said, now they are come;
Be nimble now, and helpe to fit Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Alas, must I weare this doublet? it would yield
Heaven knowes how much to burne.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You may be desparate
When 'tis on, and burne your body with it, sir,

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I sha'not know my selfe.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Be that time we ha' done wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Fit as they were made, sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Which is Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am the man you please to call Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Then I congratulate your happy fortune;
Y'are like to be exalted, his Grace talkes
Much on you, I'll be proud to be your servant:
My Lord, a word.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The Bridegroom, Sir, in great favour, I can tell you,
And new created by his Highnesse, Baron
Of Landskip; his living is far off.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My very good Lord, my breeches are almost on.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There be the Keyes.
sp.stage: Takes the keys from Hornet’s pocket, and gives them aside to Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: His Grace has pleas'd to shine upon
A piece of barren earth.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You are too modest;
The King has been informed, Sir Giles, you are
One of the ablest men in his Dominion:
Should vertue still be cloath'd in rags? Advance it
To honour, and regard you waste your braine
At home, in cheap and low engagements, sweat
Your soule out, for a poore and paltry living;
Old houses, let 'em fall to the dull Lord
O'th' Manner; switch me up a Towne together,
Or meddle not; This or that sttragling Acre's
Not worth your care; Study some Monopoly,
May sweep the Kingdome at a stake; Despise
A project wo'not bring in halfe the City;
Finde out a way to forfeit all the Charters;
Have an Exchequer of your owne, and keep
The Princes round about in pension:
These are becomming businesses, and speake
An active State-man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You do talk strange things,
My Lord.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: His keyes are things verie
Materiall to our businesse.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And I have 'em.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so:
I will account it one of my felicities,
To be a witnesse of your Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, my good Lord of Landskip.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How shall we dispose these?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Hang-man will not have them, and I feare,
They will corrupt a well; 'faith give them stable roome.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: My Lord, the King asks for you; Good Sir Giles
Write me i'th' number of your faithfull friends.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We must attend.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do not yet say he's ready,
The Barber has a dutie to dispatch,
He will be houres a rubbing, washing, powdering.
Then I'll attend him to his Presence.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We shall excuse him so long, still your servant.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Barber, sir, attends in the next roome.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I wo'not shave.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He feares his throat.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I never give above three-pence.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Talk not you of charge,
You have but yet your welcome: do not you
Think, good sir Giles, but we can shave you too.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Street near Mistresse Bellamy's House
Enter Close and Startup in his shirt.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where is he, Close?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I told him, sir,
You lay in a chamber o'th t'other side,
The house, whither he is gone with his sword drawne,
And curses of themselves able to kill you:
You did affront him once, and now his Mistresse
Has quite neglected him, for your love, he thinks:
He'll make you an example to all Rivals;
I'll bring your clothes hereafter, yet your feare
And running, sir, will keep you warme enough.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Honest Close, thou hast sav'd my life.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Death, is he not behind you? this way, good sir.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy's House.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Ha’ you not made a fine choyce, I did ever
Think he was false; your mother did but counterfeit
The love-sick widdow all this while, to trie him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Trie him, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She told me so her selfe,
Assuring him the state was hers, and you
At her devotion; put him to his choyce,
To take her with the wealth, or you with nothing:
What followed, you have heard, come be wise yet,
And love the Countrey Gentleman that dotes on you;
He's rich, and halfe a foole, I'll fetch him to you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My mother counterfeit? why may not Hartwell
Pretend as well as she, fearing her anger
And policie, if he refus'd her love?
I have observ'd some sorrow in his gestures,
As he were willing to deliver something,
If opportunitie would give him leave;
He cannot be so false, now I suspect
He does obey some dire necessitie:
'Twould puzzle a wise lover to be so
Severely put to't.

div.stage: Nurse brings in Hartwell in Startups clothes.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: On like a bold Captaine,
Give her a broad side, she's within your shot,
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis the foole, Why Nurse?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay, fly not before you heare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If my voyce
Betray me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Why in this shape? some trick in't,
He hides his face, I'll put him to't however,
Although the houre be unseasonable, any time
We may expresse our joy: my Nurse once told me
You were not well, and gone to bed, your health
Is welcome as my owne; I dare not, sir,
In modestie presume to bid you stay,
And to requite your paines, kind Mr. Startup.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: She knowes me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Forgive me if I blush,
I have no other way, but to declare
My eyes that late frown'd on your love shall smile.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: On me?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: On none but you: I have beene too
Unkindly dealt withall by Hartwell, whom
How dearly I affected, good Heaven knowes:
But I have read discretion to my fancie,
And were he here, he should be witnesse of
My vowes to you, if you accept my heart,
And can with equall truth embrace it, I
Will chuse my husband here; you, only you,
This faith be registred in Heaven, shall challenge from me a wives obedience.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Planet-struck.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, your mother's up; I wo'd not for
A thousand pound she find you in this chamber.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I have undone my selfe.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Startup, to your owne lodging,
Take that close lanthorne with you:
Passion of me, what makes her rise?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I will discover yet.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Discover; what?
Ha, Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You ha' midnight plots.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Oh, we are wretched, miserable, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Oh, who shall lead me to a world where are
No women? Farewell all, I'll be above
Your charms, and find out death, a cure for love.
